Power.comm: The tool has lots of power.

cont.entity_a: Works great with serious power despite its small size, making it ideal for automotive use. Powerful enough to run a 2-inch Roloc wheel or carbide bur bit.
Less vibration compared to other models, providing a smooth operation. Some users reported minor vibration at full throttle, but it is generally low.
Quieter than other grinders like Husky.

The tool is durable, having lasted for years even with daily use and rough conditions. Made with solid aluminum parts, promising durability. Build quality is comparable to higher-end brands like Ingersoll Rand and Mac.
cont.entity_b: Plastic housing can lead to thread stripping over time. Frequently comes apart, requiring regular repairs.

cont.entity_a: The safety device on the handle takes some getting used to but becomes second nature quickly.
cont.entity_b: Lacks a trigger lock-out, which is a desirable safety feature.

cont.entity_a: Compact and fits into tight spaces, useful for various tasks like cleaning gasket surfaces and prepping for painting. Has a good weight balance and is comfortable to hold for extended periods.
cont.entity_b: Ergonomic design. Light and easy to control for speed and angle adjustments.

cont.entity_a: Can leak oil around the air vents, which may cause surface contamination during finish work. Requires frequent oiling to maintain optimal performance and longevity.
Uses a considerable amount of air to operate, requiring a large compressor for continuous use. Requires a compressor that can produce sufficient CFM for optimal performance.
Exhaust vents to the front, which can blow cold air onto the hand during use.
Small, powerful, and suitable for professional-grade work.
cont.entity_b: Not recommended due to operational issues like the collet loosening and head coming apart.
The collet does not tighten securely, affecting tool stability.
The head keeps coming loose, which is a recurring issue.
